website_summaries.verdict: Abstract physics concepts come to life with this hands-on structural building kit.
pros: A practical way to learn physics concepts like load, tension, force, and compression
cons: Anchor pins are challenging to remove from assembled projects when it's time to build another

customer_reviews.title: Frustrating to take the anchor pins out
customer_reviews.text: Unfortunately this toy is not an enjoyable one for my child. Once you make one structure, it is not easy to take anchor pins out to make the next one. When I get one interesting toy, my child usually plays with it all day by himself but this one only frustrated him. It comes with so many small parts but there’s no container you can keep. Now I see that all these 5 star reviews are from ones who received it for free.
customer_reviews.author: P. Shin

customer_reviews.title: Good learning experience with kids
customer_reviews.text: Built different bridges with my son and tested them with weight until they failed. One held 20lbs. Fun toy!
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Stings are difficult to incorporate!
customer_reviews.text: My son loves building and spends hours doing so. I purchased this item to continue his interest and this was a huge disappointment. My 9 yr old struggled to get through a project on this and after days of trying he gave he gave up...that was a first for me to see! He never gives up....The strings are difficult to incorporate and can become very frustrating. This review was written with the intent that the creator makes some modification to the product for ease of use.
customer_reviews.author: De Ann

customer_reviews.title: Great Product & Direct Customer Service
customer_reviews.text: Great product and direct Thames & Kosmos customer service! I purchased this product for my 10-year old for Christmas. In the midst of him building the structure, he realized there was a part missing in the kit. I contacted Thames & Kosmos directly, and they sent out the replacement part that day - very friendly and customer-service oriented. I would highly recommend not only Thames & Kosmos as a company but their products as well. I will definitely be buying more kits in the near future.
customer_reviews.author: T1704

customer_reviews.title: Good if you have a child who likes to build
customer_reviews.text: I got this for my 11 year old nephew and my sister said he really enjoyed it. He has shown interest in the construction of bridges and buildings for a couple years. If he wasn't already interested in structural engineering, he would not have liked this kit.
customer_reviews.author: Albert

customer_reviews.title: Great thinking tool
customer_reviews.text: My grandson is 11 yrs old and he really enjoys this it is a big bonus to see him playing with and building using his imagination also few things tears him away from his video games so that he really liked this was a huge win i really recommend
customer_reviews.author: rebeca

customer_reviews.title: Four Stars
customer_reviews.text: Good model, informative booklet. some diagrammes too small for old eyes!
customer_reviews.author: lyricat86@live.ca

customer_reviews.title: Daughter loves this!
customer_reviews.text: My daughter absolutely loved getting this for Christmas, she was excited it wasn’t just another girly craft project that I normally get her.
customer_reviews.author: frl89

customer_reviews.title: Bridges and skyscrapers
customer_reviews.text: I am giving this book to a teenager interested in engineering.
customer_reviews.author: Gerrit Bilkes

customer_reviews.title: Parts are plastic, not metal
customer_reviews.text: My 13 year old son really enjoys this. Only downside, and the reason for 4 stars, is that the pieces are plastic; not metal. The picture on the box makes the pieces look like they’re metal, but they aren’t. They aren’t made of cheap, flimsy plastic, though. They’re quite durable and have plenty of flexibility. Overall, we’re quite satisfied.
customer_reviews.author: Juliann Farrand

customer_reviews.title: Knowledge and building
customer_reviews.text: Excellent, he loved it. When they have enough “little bricks” this was a great gift we worked on together.
customer_reviews.author: The Mysterious Mr. E.

customer_reviews.title: Awesome product great value
customer_reviews.text: Got this from my son he absolutely loves it plus a keeps him busy he wants to be an engineer I rather have him build than playing video games
customer_reviews.author: Mark weed

customer_reviews.title: Skews to an older age group than described
customer_reviews.text: This is a little complicated for my 7yr old son, but he’s excited to build it. Just needs help doing so.
customer_reviews.author: sfmom

customer_reviews.title: He loved it.
customer_reviews.text: Bought for my grandsons 7th birthdays loved it,,he is a engineer.
customer_reviews.author: dave

customer_reviews.title: Much fun!
customer_reviews.text: Provided a nice challenge. Like that you can make several types of bridges.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Fun!
customer_reviews.text: My 8 and 12 year old loved it! They could build together. Not too easy for 12 year old.
customer_reviews.author: S. McGinnis

customer_reviews.title: great gift for nephew that likes to build
customer_reviews.text: great gift for nephew that likes building and constructing things
customer_reviews.author: greg stalnaker

customer_reviews.title: Worth the money
customer_reviews.text: I gave to my 7year old nephew for a birthday present. He absolutely loved it and has built a few of the structures with his father.
customer_reviews.author: peter sheahan

customer_reviews.title: Great beginner's learning tool for structural engineering
customer_reviews.text: Great gift for high school students to learn basic structures engineering.
customer_reviews.author: georges el-gharib

customer_reviews.title: Loved it
customer_reviews.text: My 11 year old daughter loves this she got it for Christmas.
customer_reviews.author: Holly

customer_reviews.title: Does not come in brown box
customer_reviews.text: Disappointed this didn't come in a box 😕 nothing like coming home with your son and seeing his Christmas present on the front porch. Product great. My kid loves it.
customer_reviews.author: Emily Rademacher

customer_reviews.title: Great gift
customer_reviews.text: This was a present for my nephew he loved as well as his parents
customer_reviews.author: Eva

customer_reviews.title: Better for older elementary students
customer_reviews.text: My kids usually love these kits by Thames & Kosmos. Unfortunely, this one fell short on what my boys call the "awesome scale" I think they were hoping for a sturdier bridge that they could put alot of weight on. The materials that came with the kit were more on the flimsy side. I think it would fascinate kids around 10 or so but any older, I would think their would want to help engineer themselves while building.
customer_reviews.author: Redz

customer_reviews.title: amazing resource!
customer_reviews.text: great product from a great company! some of the other review complaints were true but the problems were easily adjusted for. For example, it is true the anchoring pins were difficult to remove (they need to be so the structure won't fall!). BUUUUUUTTTTT guess what????? Tah-dah! a little pliers for the garage and PROBLEM SOLVED. Another person complained the text of the manual was too small for old eyes. I had the same problem, but fortunately i have invested a fortune in a incredibly expensive rocket science tool: READING GLASSES!!!! (humor in case you thought I was serious). Please support this company THEY ARE TOTALLY THE BEST THING TO HIT STEM EDUCATION!!!!
customer_reviews.author: Bradley Johnson

customer_reviews.title: A must have.
customer_reviews.text: Wow. A great educational tool for my boys! Not only did they have fun building things with this, they really understood why things worked like they did. My older boy really took to this and even explained to me why certain pieces needed to go in certain places. This is exactly what I'd hope for when we go this. A lot of educational toys end up in the bottom of their closet, but this one is a top shelf item for sure.
customer_reviews.author: Mick McArt

customer_reviews.title: Failure
customer_reviews.text: Maybe it’s the black and grey pieces that give this kit a heavy, unfriendly look. Or it could be the uniformly small pieces – except for the smoke-colored plastic sheeting – that makes it look like an uninspiring build. The black string – yes, string(see pic) – that is supposed to mimic cabling for bridges and other tension designs, is another negative feature. This kit is neither vibrantly colored and whimsical like their(which we loved) or engaging like theset. It’s interesting, but in a dry, academic way. My 13-year-oldlost interest after the bridge models. I give this kit an A for effort – the manual is outstanding – but a D for execution. Sorry, but this is a three-star product.
customer_reviews.author: Melanie Gilbert

customer_reviews.title: Fantastic
customer_reviews.text: Quite simply a fantastic toy for real thinkers and builders. I love that it has lego-like flexibility (2 dozen projects in the instructions alone - plus infinite others from your imagination), with a higher functionality than simple bricks - that translates to a more real-world aesthetic. Highly recommended for the builder child (or adult) to enjoy.
customer_reviews.author: Oliver DeMille, TJEd

customer_reviews.title: Had a lot of fun with my 9 year old putting this together
customer_reviews.text: Had a lot of fun with my 9 year old putting this together. Its a bit beyond her skill set but between the two of us we designed and built the bridge. Your child would really need to be motivated to complete this on their own but it is a lot of fun to help!
customer_reviews.author: David J. Serra

customer_reviews.title: Tremendous, Educative
customer_reviews.text: This is an amazingly educational toy, that the clear included instructions does such a wonderful job of explaining what it is you're learning. Sturdy construction means this will not be broken easily as it's being used. Excellent quality for the price.
customer_reviews.author: Fred Woodbridge

customer_reviews.title: This kit is a great STEM building system for boys or girls
customer_reviews.text: This kit is a great STEM building system for boys or girls. It comes with a book that outlines the physics and structures behind the designs. Kids can start with simple structures and then build those into more complex designs like skyscrapers or bridges. I love the way it builds from simple ideas to complicated ones. This would be a great gift for the child who has an interest in STEM fields.
customer_reviews.author: Cara Putman

customer_reviews.title: Excellent introduction to design-of-experiments; a digital accompaniment may be needed for sustaining interest
customer_reviews.text: This is a well-constructed set of building blocks that can form the basis for a true "design of experiments" introduction to any budding engineer/architect. The core concepts of design factors, their impact on strength (how much wind is needed to shake this bridge? how many cars can this bridge support without bending? etc...) can be taught in an entertaining manner. While the experiments are limited, they are sufficient to help develop an engineering frame-of-mind. One wishes, Thames&Kosmos create a digital accompaniment to this so that the kids can have some degree of interactivity after the models have been built. Without that interactivity, no matter how fun the engineering lesson, the ipad is going to steal away the kids!
customer_reviews.author: Jijnasu Forever

customer_reviews.title: instructional, educational, fun for the whole family
customer_reviews.text: The “Structural Engineering” building kit from Thames & Kosmos arrives in a well organized box and contains an excellent 45 page instructional manual for your aspiring architect or builder. Inside are 24 categories of parts and assembly tools, some Newtonian advice on “vectors, forces and moments,” 323 rubber pieces (grouped and wrapped in plastic) for 24 experiments building skyscrapers, bridges, and towers. Not only a play kit, it is instructional and educational, aimed at the 8 - 14 ages child and teenager.
customer_reviews.author: JEDrury

customer_reviews.title: cool set for your builder
customer_reviews.text: I am not sold that these are better than say legos, but these are a nice structured set for those little ones that like to have a directed task. I see this set working really well in a STEM camp or an after school organization / club. Great examples and ideas.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Didn't engage my 9 year old builder
customer_reviews.text: My 9 year old can follow any lego instructions and build anything with legos, but found this set super frustrating. He built one unrecognizable structure and then it sat in his closet for several months. He found the pieces difficult to snap together, which made it hard to take apart and build something new. He also wasn't inspired by the idea of building bridges like I thought he might be. I thought it needed something more to engage younger children. If you have a child who's into building bridges or skyscrapers specifically then this might interest them, or if you have ideas to make it more engaging, this might work for you. Otherwise, I'd pass on this one.
customer_reviews.author: Debra

customer_reviews.title: very good,tough material!🙌
customer_reviews.text: A great gift,but what caught our attention is the resistance of the pieces,things that are usually not in these toys.🙌
customer_reviews.author: Jashvant Jaiswal

customer_reviews.title: Good Start To Learning Structural Engineering
customer_reviews.text: The first thing my son built was a house that wasn't in the plans. He actually did a very nice job. The instructions are good, the brief structure tips are interesting and the kit is basically a good price. The material is made from good plastics. I think where this kit fails in this day and age is that once you have completed your project it doesn't do anything. I guess you can place LEGO characters on it for display.
customer_reviews.author: Steve Taylor

customer_reviews.title: Educational and enjoyable fun
customer_reviews.text: Calling all future engineers. This set is perfect for the kid who loves building blocks, but would like something a bit more focused on structural engineering than the typical Lego set. This gives kids a real opportunity to gain insight on what makes structures more or less stable. Most of the pieces are pretty sturdy, and are made with hard plastic. The roadway is made from flexible plastic sheeting. There are 20 different things they can build with the manual but in reality they are only limited by their imagination. I'd say the age range of 8-14 is fairly accurate. This is a great set for the kid who loves knowing how things work, and enjoys hands on building.
customer_reviews.author: Georgia Mom

customer_reviews.title: Excellent learning tool for kids
customer_reviews.text: Great way for kids to learn how to build stronger structures. The book has good building activities and information. We use this to supplement a robotics summer camp.
customer_reviews.author: Charles

customer_reviews.title: Trusted brand
customer_reviews.text: Now I may not have bought it but my friend has this kit, I showed him Thames & Kosmos and he is obsessed. I have many of their kits and plan to buy more. Their kits always contain tools needed to remove pieces if necessary.
customer_reviews.author: Billy

product_meta.title: Thames & Kosmos Structural Engineering: Bridges & Skyscrapers | Science & Engineering Kit | Build 20 Models | Learn About Force, Load, Compression, Tension | Parents' Choice Gold Award Winner, Blue
product_meta.description: Style:Structural EngineeringDo you ever wonder how bridges span huge distances and how skyscrapers stay standing? Structural engineers use physics and their knowledge of the properties of building materials and geometric shapes to design structures with sufficient strength and stability. With this kit of modular building pieces, you can learn the basics of structural engineering by conducting a series of 20 model-building experiments. Each model demonstrates a basic principle of mechanical physics or structural engineering in a hands-on way. Start out with small models that demonstrate how structural elements can be attached together to maximize the strength of a structure for a fixed amount of material used. Learn about basic structural elements including columns, beams, trusses, plates, arches, shells, and catenary. Explore the forces acting on structural components including tension, compression, shear, and bending. Move onto building more complex models of trusses, roofs, and small buildings. Experiment with different types of bridge construction: a truss bridge, arch bridge, cantilever bridge, rope bridge, and suspension bridge. Finally, build models of towering skyscrapers. What is the tallest tower you can build using only the pieces included in the kit? Learn about the strength and stiffness of materials. See how structural engineers optimize factors to maximize safety, and minimize cost and the risk of structural failure. A 36-page, full-color manual guides you through model building with step-by-step illustrated instructions.
feature_bullets: Build 20 different models that each teach about force, load, compression, tension and more
Includes 36-page, illustrated experiment manual and Assembly guide
